detail.title: The Procedure for the Prompt Release of Vessels and Crews: Pragmatic? Predictable? Passé?

publicationDetails.detailsText: Suzanne Lalonde & Andrew Serdy (eds.), Research Handbook on the Law of the Sea (Edward Elgar, 1. ed. 2026)

detail.abstract: The prompt release procedure set out in Article 292 of UNCLOS enables flag States to seek the release of their vessels and crews from coastal State detention "upon the posting of a reasonable bond or other financial security". While this procedure is designed to help balance the rights of flag States and vessel operators with the broad enforcement powers given to coastal States for alleged infringements of fisheries and environmental protection laws and regulations in the EEZ, giving effect to that balance in practice has proved more complicated. After the passage of thirty years and ten prompt release applications, this chapter examines the theory and practice of prompt release, to understand what has worked and what has not, and consider what the future might hold for this unique feature of UNCLOS.

AI.tldr: 本文探讨了《联合国海洋法公约》第292条规定的迅速释放程序，分析了其在实践中的平衡作用及未来前景。
AI.research_question: 《联合国海洋法公约》第292条规定的迅速释放程序在实践中如何平衡船旗国与沿海国的权利？
AI.motivation: 尽管迅速释放程序旨在平衡船旗国和沿海国的权利，但实践中的复杂性促使研究其实际效果和未来发展方向。
AI.theoretical_framework: 《联合国海洋法公约》第292条及相关国际海洋法理论。
AI.method: 通过分析30年间的10个迅速释放申请案例，评估理论与实践。
AI.findings: 迅速释放程序在实践中存在复杂性，未能完全实现预期的平衡效果。
AI.theory_contributions: 深化了对迅速释放程序理论的理解，揭示了理论与实践之间的差距。
AI.practical_contributions: 为未来改进迅速释放程序提供了实践依据和政策建议。

title: Allocative Justice as a Constraint on Fiscal Imperialism in International Tax
affiliations: Independent and Dalhousie University - Schulich School of Law

detail.title: Allocative Justice as a Constraint on Fiscal Imperialism in International Tax
detail.abstract:
Taxpayers’ cross-border activities often result in two (or more) states claiming the right to tax their income. To address concerns about how those tax liabilities might aggregate and suppress international activities, states typically agree to split the tax base between them. But how can states fairly share tax revenue from cross-border activities?

Tax scholars and policymakers offer different normative perspectives to address this inter-nation equity conundrum. In this article, we conceptualize these normative perspectives into two types. One centres on identifying where the economic factors that lead to the ability to produce the income are located (and uses that determination as the basis for an equitable split of taxing rights). Accordingly, a state with a greater degree of economic connection should enjoy a greater share of taxing rights. This perspective, we contend, is distinguishable from the infusion of cosmopolitan distributive justice theory into tax law. The latter approach portrays the redistribution or transfer of tax revenue, a form of tax aid from high-income countries to low-income countries, usually with the goal of funding humanitarian or developmental spending...

AI.tldr: 本文探讨了如何公平分配跨国活动的税收收入，提出了两种规范性视角：一种基于经济联系程度分配征税权，另一种基于全球分配正义理论进行税收援助。
AI.research_question: 国家如何公平分享跨国活动的税收收入？
AI.motivation: 跨国活动导致多国对同一收入征税，可能抑制国际经济活动，因此需要公平的税收分配机制。
AI.theoretical_framework: 经济联系视角与全球分配正义理论。
AI.method: 概念化两种规范性视角并分析其差异。
AI.findings: 经济联系视角主张按经济联系程度分配征税权，而全球分配正义理论支持税收援助从高收入国家流向低收入国家。
AI.theory_contributions: 区分了两种税收分配规范性视角，丰富了国际税收理论。
AI.practical_contributions: 为政策制定者提供了分配跨国税收收入的两种思路。

title: Liberalization of Japan's Oilseeds Markets Under a Canada-Japan EPA

detail.title: Liberalization of Japan's Oilseeds Markets Under a Canada-Japan EPA
detail.abstract: This study evaluates the potential impacts on Canada's canola sector of the elimination of Japan's tariffs on crude and refined canola oil under a prospective Canada-Japan Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA). Japan currently applies specific tariffs of ¥10.9/kg on crude canola oil and ¥13.2/kg on refined oil, while allowing duty-free imports of canola seed. This tariff escalation structure distorts trade by discouraging value-added exports from Canada, resulting in minimal processing activity in Canada for products destined for the Japanese market and allowing Japanese crushers to capture almost all downstream value-added. The analysis combines simulations using a multi-country partial equilibrium model (GSIM) with additional market structure considerations to estimate the order of magnitude of gains from tariff elimination. The study also highlights the need for negotiations to secure not only tariff reductions but also effective market access in Japan's vertically integrated downstream market.

detail.title: Extrapolative Expectations and Asset Returns: Evidence from Chinese Mutual Funds
detail.abstract: Do professional investors fall prey to behavioral biases like return extrapolation? We study how mutual funds form market expectations using a novel text-based measure derived from Chinese regulatory disclosures. Fund managers extrapolate from recent returns, placing more weight on recent performance-a tendency that weakens with experience. Aggregate expectations positively predict short-term market returns, both in and out of sample. At the fund level, beliefs predict performance only when portfolios are adjusted accordingly. This effect is stronger for bullish forecasts and among funds with liquid holdings. Belief-driven performance thus hinges on both forecasting skill and execution flexibility.

title: Theory of Online Market Gravity  - Principle 4:  Limits of Asymmetric Efficiency

detail.title: Theory of Online Market Gravity  - Principle 4:  Limits of Asymmetric Efficiency

declarations.declarationOfInterest: This is fleshed out version of The Work I have already done with the Jevon's paradox integrating insights from my work on systems theory. It is related to the endeavor that I have started at The Job Applicant Perspective but the reasoning motivates the business not the other way around. I seek to publish the literature to make it more accessible to others so that the danger of the online labor markets can be more fully visible for those with eyes to see and more can be done to help.

detail.abstract:
This paper introduces Principle 4: The Micah Paradox as the natural outcome of the principles of the Theory of Online Market Gravity (Trumble 2025a–c). Drawing on systems theory, labor economics, and platform design, this paper shows how one-sided optimization by platforms and employers leads to brittle market conditions. A typology of false stabilization distinguishes between relational and transactional mechanisms of decay. Rather than isolated failure, the dysfunction is mapped as a multi-actor breakdown in governance and trust architecture. An archetype of this point is the online labor markets. While digital platforms for hiring claim to increase efficiency, they often produce the opposite: rising ghost jobs, prolonged unemployment, and eroding trust among job seekers. This paradox is not incidental but structural. It arises from false stabilization—where markets appear functional by suppressing feedback loops rather than resolving tensions. The paper concludes with policy and design recommendations for rebuilding market gravity through feedback symmetry, verified closure, and platform transparency.

This paper is Part 4 of 5 in the Theory of Online Market Gravity (Trumble 2025), a structural framework for understanding the nature—and as relevant— dysfunction of digital platforms and online markets. The full framework comprises:

  • Principle 1: Markets Optimize What They Measure

  • Principle 2: The Tension Is the Market

  • Principle 3: The Two-Sided Trust Principle (Aurora Principle)

  • Principle 4: The Limits of Asymmetric Efficiency (Micah Paradox)

  • Principle 5: The Conditional Belonging Principle

Together, these five principles explain how digital markets collapse when platforms suppress friction, eliminate user feedback, and replace reciprocal trust with engagement metrics. Each paper can be read independently or as part of a broader systems-theoretical account of market gravity in the digital age.

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declares no competing interests. This research was conducted independently without any personal, financial, or institutional conflict of interest.

detail.abstract: Global remittance systems remain burdened by high costs, regulatory friction, and foreign exchange risk. This white paper proposes a scalable, FX-free, tax-efficient alternative based on gold-backed transfers. The model leverages globally recognized custodians with multi-country vault operations (e.g., Brink's Global Services, Loomis International) and local short-term lending mechanisms to execute cross-border remittances without triggering foreign currency transactions or tax events under schemes such as India's Liberalised Remittance Scheme (LRS). Rather than challenge the dominance of existing currencies (e.g., USD) or networks (e.g., SWIFT), this architecture presents itself as a neutral, complementary layer for corridors underserved by current financial infrastructure. Gold serves not only as a store of value but as a stable, recognized medium for inter-jurisdictional settlement.

title: Misunderstanding the Legal Framework Applicable to the Single Supervisory Mechanism. Silvio Berlusconi vs the European Central Bank (Case T-913/16 and Joined Cases C-512/22 P and C-513/22 P)
affiliations: University of Edinburgh

detail.title: Misunderstanding the Legal Framework Applicable to the Single Supervisory Mechanism. Silvio Berlusconi vs the European Central Bank (Case T-913/16 and Joined Cases C-512/22 P and C-513/22 P)

publicationDetails.detailsText: European Banking Institute Working Paper Series No. 196
publicationDetails.journalName: European Banking Institute (EBI) Research Paper Series

detail.abstract:
On 19 September 2024 the Court of Justice delivered its decision in the two joined appeal cases mentioned in the title. It was the end of an administrative and judicial saga spanning more than a decade, involving national and EU administrative authorities and various courts at the Member State (Italy) and EU level. It included national and EU administrative decisions with proceedings before Italian and EU administrative courts, as well as a preliminary ruling from the Court of Justice on the interpretation of the relevant provisions of Regulation (EU) 1024/2014 (the Single Supervisory Mechanism Regulation, SSMR in short).[1]

The sum of all those acts and decisions is a remarkable judicial case, whose wrong conclusions must be mostly ascribed to the errors of facts committed by the General Court. As shown in the paper, had the General Court correctly assessed the facts of the case, the ECB’s decision would have never been annulled in appeal. This notwithstanding, the retroactivity analysis of prudential requirements enshrined in European law since 1989 in the appeal judgment is difficult to comprehend and also cause for concern. 

In the end, the Berlusconi case can be considered a failed test for the effectiveness of judicial protection in European prudential supervision. 

[1] Council Regulation (EU) No 1024/2013 of 15 October 2013 conferring specific tasks on the European Central Bank concerning policies relating to the prudential supervision of credit institutions, OJ L 287, 29.10.2013, pp. 63–89.

title: A Model of Rating and Matchmaking
affiliations: Fukuoka University

detail.title: A Model of Rating and Matchmaking
detail.abstract: Online multiplayer games have grown into a global industry, where competitive play depends critically on rating systems and matchmaking algorithms that estimate player skill and form balanced matches. The effectiveness of such systems hinges on the accuracy of ratings in capturing underlying ability. However, models like Elo typically rely on discrete, nonlinear updates from binary outcomes, which pose analytical challenges. To address this, the present study introduces a Gaussian framework in which match outcomes are treated as continuous noisy observations of relative skill. This setting enables explicit characterization of the evolution of rating-skill correlation and the conditions under which the rating distribution converges to a stationary state. The impact of key design parameters-such as update intensity and the degree of skill-based matching-on both convergence speed and long-run rating accuracy is examined. In settings where these parameters may vary over time, the trajectory that maximizes rating-skill correlation is derived and shown to coincide with the optimal estimator among a broad class of nonparametric update rules. The results provide a tractable and rigorous foundation for evaluating rating systems and offer guidance for designing effective learning mechanisms in dynamic competitive environments.

title: The Forgotten Binary Paradigm in Modern Fiduciary Law
affiliations: Stetson University - College of Law

detail.title: The Forgotten Binary Paradigm in Modern Fiduciary Law

publicationDetails.detailsText: Stetson University College of Law Research Paper Forthcoming
publicationDetails.journalName: Stetson University College of Law Legal Studies Research Paper Series

detail.abstract:
This Article identifies a fundamental but overlooked distinction in fiduciary law: fiduciary relationships exist in two qualitatively different forms that create vastly different consequences for personal liability.  In “principal-agent relationships,” principals retain complete control rights and face vicarious liability for their agents’ wrongdoing.  In “beneficiary-trustee relationships,” beneficiaries possess only beneficial control rights while trustees possess management control rights, in addition to control duties—shielding beneficiaries from automatic vicarious liability.

Current law obscures this distinction through imprecise nomenclature.  Courts label attorneys “independent contractors” when denying vicarious liability for attorney wrongdoing yet acknowledge their fiduciary status.  The Restatement (Second) of Agency compounds this confusion by creating the contradictory category of fiduciaries who are simultaneously “independent contractors” and “agents.”  The Restatement (Third) of Agency abandons the term, “independent contractor,” altogether.  This conceptual muddle extends to corporate law, where identical rules govern both closely held corporations (resembling principal-agent relationships) and public corporations (resembling beneficiary-trustee relationships).

The Article proposes the following terminology: “agents” for controlled fiduciaries whose principals face vicarious liability; “trustees” for autonomous fiduciaries whose beneficiaries avoid such liability; and “independent contractors” exclusively for non-fiduciary relationships.  This framework helps clarify several doctrinal issues—from attorney-client liability to corporate veil-piercing to the scope of corporate constitutional rights.  By making this implicit binary structure explicit, this Article provides a conceptual framework for determining when those who benefit from fiduciary relationships should bear responsibility for fiduciary misconduct.  The result is a more nuanced law of fiduciary obligations that appropriately distinguishes between economic incentives and managerial control.

AI.tldr: 本文揭示了信托法中一个基本但被忽视的区别：信托关系以两种形式存在，对个人责任产生截然不同的后果。一种是“委托-代理关系”，委托人保留完全控制权并承担代理人的不当行为责任；另一种是“受益人-受托人关系”，受益人仅享有受益权，受托人享有管理权和控制义务，从而避免受益人的自动连带责任。
AI.research_question: 信托关系中两种不同形式如何影响个人责任？

AI.findings: 提出明确的术语框架：“代理人”适用于委托人承担责任的受控信托关系，“受托人”适用于受益人免于责任的自主信托关系，“独立承包商”仅适用于非信托关系。

title: Phase-2: Reimagining Global Monetary Standards: A Lifespan-Linked and Contribution-Based Framework for Post-Fiat Reserve Currencies
affiliations: Gautam Buddha University and Gautam Buddha University

detail.title: Phase-2: Reimagining Global Monetary Standards: A Lifespan-Linked and Contribution-Based Framework for Post-Fiat Reserve Currencies
detail.abstract: The foundations of global finance are increasingly strained by the volatility of fiat systems, geopolitical dominance in currency valuation, and the speculative nature of reserve accumulation. This paper proposes a technologically grounded and ethically structured alternative: the Standard Crypto Reserve (SCR), a decentralized, contribution-indexed, and lifespan-anchored reserve currency system. Drawing on institutional economics, modern monetary theory, and blockchain-based governance, SCR redefines reserve legitimacy not through GDP or capital holdings, but through verified human lifespan and measurable national contributions in education, innovation, governance, sustainability, and many such parameters. The proposed framework introduces a dual-vault architecture, comprising global and national reserves, with algorithmically regulated issuance based on a Contribution Index (CI). National currencies are valued proportionally to their SCR reserve and performance across socioeconomic indicators. The study contrasts SCR with central bank digital currencies (CBDCs), the IMF's Special Drawing Rights (SDRs), and commoditybacked systems, arguing for SCR's superiority in terms of structural transparency, ethical scarcity, and economic inclusivity (Catalini & Gans, 2016; Yermack, 2013; Auer et al., 2020). Empirical support is proposed through dynamic general equilibrium modelling and comparative scenario simulations across pre-and post-crisis economies. By anchoring monetary value to verifiable life and contribution, SCR offers a globally interoperable and inflation-resilient standard, empowering emerging economies through performance-based inclusion and algorithmic trust. This paper advances the discourse on post-fiat reform and proposes SCR as a viable path toward equitable and resilient financial architecture.

title: Different Spanks for Different Ranks: a Critical Appraisal of Character Evidence in Courts-Martial
affiliations: Mississippi College - School of Law

detail.title: Different Spanks for Different Ranks: a Critical Appraisal of Character Evidence in Courts-Martial

declarations.declarationOfInterest: This is a forthcoming chapter in Bennett Capers, Jasmine Harris, Julia Simon-Kerr (eds.), CRITICAL EVIDENCE (2025).

detail.abstract:
This chapter explores character evidence in the U.S. military’s court-martial system. Courts-martial, unlike civilian criminal trials, permit defendants to present evidence of their own good character even when the character traits are not pertinent to the charged offenses. This derogation has been cheered by some as giving military defendants an extra tool to fight back in a system that is stacked against them. But concerns about expansive use of character evidence soon became apparent: it tends to distort and confuse the issues in trial, and disproportionately benefits only high-status defendants. For all its good intentions, liberalized military character evidence became a tool of impunity for powerful military defendants and a contributing factor to a sexual assault epidemic in the ranks.

Part II provides a basic overview of the U.S. court-martial system. Part III describes the military’s character evidence rules, including the novel “good soldier defense” which erased the usual limitation that defendants are only allowed to raise “pertinent” character traits; instead, any servicemember could present evidence of their good military character regardless of the charge. After some troubling results of defendants wielding the “good soldier defense,” Congress eventually attempted to reign it in, but seems to have merely driven it underground. Regardless of what the character evidence rules say, courts-martial also heavily involve unofficial and unregulated character evidence. Part IV uses three examples – a scene from “A Few Good Men” and two real courts-martial – to show how unofficial character evidence such as military rank and decorations can shape court-martial outcomes in ways that evade formal evidentiary gatekeeping.

detail.title: Accelerating Bus Electrification in the United States: Legal Instruments and Interventions for Transit Agencies and the Federal Transit Administration
detail.abstract: Public transit agencies can significantly reduce local air pollution and the transport sector's impact on climate change by switching from diesel buses to electric buses. Since low-income residents heavily rely on public transit and disproportionately live in neighborhoods where public transit buses traverse, removing air pollutants such as particulate matter from transit bus tailpipe emissions would achieve greater environmental justice. Although most major transit agencies had planned to complete bus electrification by 2040, many have fallen behind schedule. The inability of manufacturers to sufficiently improve electric bus technology and reduce unit costs, combined with transit agencies' hesitation to procure electric buses in significant quantities, has placed both stakeholders in a negative feedback loop, resulting in the stagnation of bus electrification in the United States. This paper describes several legal instruments available to transit agencies and proposes several legal interventions that transit agencies can implement immediately to enhance the outlook of the electric bus market and procure electric buses more cost-effectively, thus pushing transit agencies and manufacturers out of stagnation. This paper also identifies legal interventions federal agencies can implement to facilitate bus electrification in the United States. Interagency collaboration and federal coordination can increase the effectiveness of the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act and the Inflation Act in greening America's public transportation and revitalizing American manufacturing.

detail.abstract: We examine how tariffs affect sectoral composition and welfare in an economy with nonhomothetic preferences and sectors being complements---key drivers of structural change. Beyond their conventional role in trade protection, tariffs influence industrial structure by altering relative prices and income levels. We qualitatively characterize these mechanisms and use a quantitative dynamic model to show that a counterfactual 20-percentage-point increase in U.S. manufacturing tariffs since 2001 would have raised the manufacturing value-added share by one percentage point and increased welfare by 0.36 percent. However, if all the U.S. trading partners responded reciprocally, U.S. welfare would have declined by 0.12 percent.

title: No Right to Counsel: Evictions, Administrative Burdens, and Access to Civil Justice
affiliations: University of Washington - Daniel J. Evans School of Public Policy and Governance and University of Washington

detail.title: No Right to Counsel: Evictions, Administrative Burdens, and Access to Civil Justice

declarations.funderStatement: This research was funded by the University of Washington Population Health Initiative and the Washington State Office of Civil Legal Aid.

detail.abstract:
As housing has become increasingly unaffordable for US renters, an access to justice crisis has emerged in local eviction courts. Millions of tenants face eviction without legal counsel each year, typically against landlords who are represented by an attorney. In response to calls from access to justice scholars and legal advocates, 25 jurisdictions have recently authorized right to counsel programs that provide legal assistance to tenants facing an eviction. While extant research has documented the many benefits of legal aid for housing-insecure tenants, less attention has been paid to the experiences of tenants who do not access legal counsel even when it is offered.

This Article reports the findings of a mixed methods empirical study of the nation’s first statewide right to counsel program for tenants facing eviction. In doing so, we make three primary contributions. First, we draw on the theoretical framework of administrative burden in order to elucidate the barriers that evicted tenants face in their pursuit of legal aid. We analyze qualitative data from interviews with tenants who were initially unable to access legal assistance and show that eviction proceedings and the right to counsel program exact learning, compliance, and psychological costs on prospective participants. We further demonstrate that tenants frequently endure traumatic experiences that strain their cognitive resources and impede their efforts to contact legal aid providers.

Second, we show that many tenants are still evicted without representation nearly three years after the implementation of Washington’s groundbreaking law. We analyze quantitative data from 970 unlawful detainer proceedings in Washington and identify predictors of tenants’ legal representation. Although these data do not allow for precise measurement of administrative burdens, we provide empirical evidence of tenants’ ability and willingness to engage with the legal process and the right to counsel program at multiple stages of the eviction process. Our analysis shows that two local rules intended to reduce default judgments against tenants are associated with lower default rates, but have not measurably increased tenant representation rates. We also find that tenants’ submission of a written response to the eviction summons is a strong predictor of access to legal representation. Finally, we add to the body of evidence that shows improved case outcomes for represented tenants. Our findings suggest that interventions focused on marginally increasing compliance burdens for landlords do not meaningfully increase tenants’ access to justice.

We conclude by arguing that policymakers should apply user-centered design practices and lessons from research on the criminal legal system to increase tenants’ participation in right to counsel programs. While right to counsel programs have dramatically improved rates of legal representation across jurisdictions, additional reforms are needed to ensure more comprehensive provision of legal aid. Right to counsel laws are a promising first step, but policymakers should further consider reforms that reduce the learning, compliance, and psychological costs of accessing legal aid by improving clarity of court communications, mitigating logistical complexity, and creating more flexibility for tenants who intend to participate in the legal process.

detail.abstract: Are carbon emissions priced in equity markets? The literature is split with different approaches yielding conflicting results. We develop a stylized model showing that, if emissions are priced, stock returns depend on expected emissions and the product of the innovation in emissions and the price-dividend ratio. Building on this insight, we derive and test new predictions. We find that emissions are priced in equity markets, but the magnitude of such pricing is highly sensitive to the inclusion of a few "super emitters" (mostly operating in electric power generation). Our theoretical insight also helps reconcile seemingly divergent results in the literature.

detail.abstract:
This written testimony was submitted to the UK House of Lords Financial Services Regulation Committee in response to the Committee’s “Call for Evidence” regarding the growth of private credit markets since the global financial crisis of 2007-09 (https://committees.parliament.uk/work/9235/growth-of-private-markets-in-the-uk-following-reforms-introduced-after-2008).  This written testimony was tendered in conjunction with the author’s oral testimony before the Committee on July 23, 2025, and addresses the following points: 
1. As past deregulatory episodes have shown, the current “global deregulatory drive” to loosen financial regulation is likely to endanger global financial markets by encouraging excessive risk-taking by large banks and further expansion of “shadow banking” activities by private equity funds, hedge funds, and other nonbank financial institutions. 

2. Strong equity capital requirements, incorporated in robust leverage capital standards, are essential to maintain the stability of the banking system and to sustain lending by banks through the business cycle.  

3. Community banks play a vital role in the U.S. economy by providing credit to consumers, farmers, and small businesses, and by supporting the civic life of smaller and rural communities.  However, community banks need greater support from Congress and regulators to maintain their viability. 

4. Large universal banks, working in conjunction with nonbank financial intermediaries (“shadow banks”), have promoted a rapid and perilous expansion of private-sector and public-sector debts since 2009.  Universal banks are supporting the growth of risky private credit obligations arranged by private equity firms as well as highly leveraged trading positions established by hedge funds in sovereign debt markets.  

5. Private equity funds face severe challenges and are exposing bank lenders and captive insurance companies to increasing risks.  Private equity funds and private credit funds are currently seeking to sell highly leveraged and illiquid investments to retail investors as well as pension funds and investment funds that serve retail investors.

6. The enormous costs of rescuing universal banks, shadow banks, and financial markets since 2007 have imposed huge fiscal burdens on governments and left central banks with bloated balance sheets.  It is very doubtful whether governments and central banks could arrange another series of large bailouts in response to a future crisis without precipitating severe and destabilizing sovereign debt crises.

7. My written testimony recommends the following reforms:
(a) Prohibiting nonbank financial institutions from offering “shadow deposits,” which are short-term, deposit-like financial claims that compete with bank deposits and are highly vulnerable to investor runs.
(b) Requiring large universal banks to hold significantly higher levels of equity capital to satisfy enhanced leverage capital requirements, and to undergo more rigorous stress tests to assess the viability and resilience of their business models,
(c) Supporting the formation of new community banks and reducing compliance burdens for those banks if they provide substantial amounts of relationship loans to small and medium-sized enterprises
(d) Implementing the Financial Stability Board’s recommendations for (i) enhanced reporting and disclosure requirements for hedge funds, private equity funds, and private credit funds; (ii) mandates requiring central clearing of government securities, repurchase agreements, derivatives, and other systemically important financial instruments; (iii) strong capital requirements for clearing facilities and robust margin requirements for their customers; and (iv) increased margin requirements, position limits, and concentration limits for significant financial instruments that are not centrally cleared.
(e) Adopting stronger reporting obligations, capital requirements, asset quality and diversification standards, and oversight procedures for life insurance and reinsurance companies that are controlled by private equity firms.
(f) Prohibiting – or establishing very strong presumptions against - offerings of private equity funds and private credit funds to retail investors or to investment funds and pension funds that serve retail investors.
(g) Restructuring financial institutions and financial markets by separating banks from securities broker-dealers and other firms engaged in capital markets activities, in accordance with principles derived from the Glass-Steagall Act of 1933

publicationDetails.journalName: United States Association for Energy Economics (USAEE) & International Association for Energy Economics (IAEE) Research Paper Series

detail.abstract: In regions with low soil fertility, smallholder farmers often clear forests to maintain agricultural yields. This pattern has particularly adverse effects where forest regrowth is slow, contributing to local forest loss and global environmental challenges such as climate change and biodiversity decline. This paper presents findings from a framed field experiment that examines how different types of monetary incentives affect forest-clearing decisions in northern Namibia, a semi-arid region with negligible forest regrowth. We implemented a common-pool resource game with 518 smallholder farmers across 25 villages, in which a forest stock declines dynamically based on participants' clearing decisions, without immediate regrowth. The game spans three periods: a baseline without incentives, an intervention period with individual or collective rewards or an individual fee, and a post-incentive phase. This setup allows us to assess both the immediate effects of incentives and their persistence after incentive removal. All incentive types reduce clearing compared to baseline, but not significantly more than in the control condition, where clearing also declined-an unexpected trend likely linked to features of the dynamic game design. Incentive effects largely dissipate after removal, with no strong evidence of lasting motivational crowding-in or crowding-out. Overall, our results suggest that moderate payments may be insufficient to sustain cooperation in persistent resource dilemmas. More broadly, they highlight the importance of multifaceted analyses including control conditions and careful experimental framing in field-laboratory studies, coupled with caution in generalizing findings to other settings or policy applications.

detail.abstract: Persistent disparities in academic achievement between students from high-and low-poverty neighborhoods are widely attributed to differences in school quality. Using nationally representative data from over 18,000 students and nearly 1,000 elementary schools, we examine how the schools serving students from different neighborhoods vary across more than 160 characteristics, including detailed measures of their composition, resources, instruction, climate, and effectiveness. Our findings document significant differences in demographic composition between schools serving high-and low-poverty neighborhoods, but comparatively little variation in other dimensions of the school environment. With novel machine learning methods tailored for high-dimensional data, we estimate that equalizing all these different factors would reduce the achievement gap by less than 10%, primarily through changes in school composition. These results suggest that the primary drivers of place-based disparities in achievement lie outside of elementary schools, underscoring the need to address broader structural inequalities as part of any effort to reduce achievement gaps.

detail.title: Technical versus Environmental Efficiency in Steel Production: A Global Perspective

detail.abstract: This study provides the first global, plant-level assessment of both technical and environmental efficiency in steel production using a novel micro-dataset covering 147 steel mills across 50 countries from 2019 to 2023. Applying a Stochastic Directional Distance Function, we estimate each plant's distance to the production frontier and compute the shadow price of CO 2 e emissions. Our results reveal a robust negative correlation between inefficiency and marginal abatement cost: technically efficient electric arc furnace (EAF) mini-mills-particularly prevalent in North America-display low inefficiency scores (∼0.2) and face high marginal abatement costs (up to 13.4 USD/ton). Conversely, integrated plants in developing countries often operate inefficiently (scores up to ∼0.8) but can abate emissions at very low cost (∼0.4 USD/ton), with Europe positioned between these two extremes. Estimated shadow prices are consistently lower than prevailing carbon market rates, highlighting a systemic under-valuation of emissions in the absence of regulatory pressure. This underpricing, in turn, reflects the highly uneven technological and economic conditions across steel plants worldwide, reinforcing the need for climate policies that account for both efficiency levels and plant configurations, and that tailor interventions to the specific costs and capacities of decarbonization.

detail.abstract: Characterized by amyloid plaques, tau tangles, and neuronal loss, Alzheimer's disease (AD) presents a significant public health challenge, with ever-growing prevalence due to an aging global population. By the time cognitive impairment is detected, the disease's pathology is already extensive and difficult to halt. Despite advances in research and drug development, participation in AD drug trials remains crucial for discovering effective treatments and preventive measures. This article explores how behavioral economics can be employed to raise global awareness about Alzheimer's, motivate individuals to undergo testing, and encourage involvement in experimental drug trials. By integrating nudging strategies with creative educational approaches, this study aims to increase support for AD research.

detail.abstract: During the late decades of the 20 th and early decades of the 21th century East Asia experienced significant economic growth. However, the Philippines diverged due to slower growth rates. By establishing new and revised historical series for historical development of GDP in purchasing power parities along with productivity series, the paper concludes that almost lack of total productivity growth caused the bad performance of the Philippines. The reason for the inferior development seem to be dysfunctional political and managerial systems, with significant corruption and lack of investments in infrastructure. The system made foreign direct investments stay low until the last approximately 15 years, when the Philippine economy started a convergence process.

detail.abstract:
In 1970s Indonesia, the government implemented a massive school construction program that transformed educational access nationwide. From 1973 to 1975, the number of schools built in each district was directly based on how many children were not enrolled in school the year before. By targeting actual educational need, Indonesia ensured a fair, data-driven approach to infrastructure development - resulting in over 61,800 new primary schools and thousands of new teaching positions by 1979. This strategic alignment between need and resource allocation is a proven model of inclusive and equitable education reform (Duflo, 2001).

In the Philippines today, nearly 11 million out-of-school youth and adults remain excluded from formal education due to the lack of accessible facilities in underserved areas (Philippine Statistics Authority, 2024). While government programs exist to promote re-enrollment and alternative learning, these efforts often fail to address the structural shortage of classrooms, particularly in rapidly growing and impoverished communities. A long-term solution must involve expanding educational infrastructure in direct proportion to the current number of unenrolled citizens.

This proposed law mandates the annual construction of new primary and secondary school facilities based on updated national and local data on out-of-school youth and adults. The Department of Education (DepEd), in coordination with the Philippine Statistics Authority (PSA) and Local Government Units (LGUs), shall publish yearly data on school accessibility gaps. For every identified deficit in access - defined by distance, class overcrowding, or unavailable grade levels - equivalent school infrastructure must be planned, budgeted, and constructed within one year.

By institutionalizing a proportionate, data-driven method for school construction, this law ensures that education is not just a constitutional right in principle, but a guaranteed public service in practice. It redefines infrastructure not as a political favor but as a measurable response to national need - laying the foundation for a generation that is educated, empowered, and ready to shape the nation’s future.

This proposal is submitted with the hope that it will be enacted for the benefit of the people.

title: Startups' Innovation Capabilities: A Systematic Literature Review to Depict Core Elements and a Performance-Driven Framework
affiliations: Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul (UFRGS), Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul (UFRGS) - Department of Industrial Engineering, Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul (UFRGS) and Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul (UFRGS)

detail.title: Startups' Innovation Capabilities: A Systematic Literature Review to Depict Core Elements and a Performance-Driven Framework
detail.abstract: Although research has extensively analyzed the innovation capabilities of established firms, a comprehensive understanding of startups' innovation capabilities remains limited. Besides, managerial research has explored the nature, antecedents, consequences, dynamic features, and dimensions of innovation capabilities, yet lacks analysis at the micro-foundation level, particularly on the constituent elements of capabilities. To address this gap, this paper aimed to analyze startups' innovation capabilities, identifying the main elements present in four capabilities-two technological and two non-technological-that support the proposition of a theoretical framework. A systematic review of 94 papers was conducted using the content analysis technique. The main elements and sub-elements that are part of the innovation context in startups and interconnected to both technological and non-technological capabilities were identified. We also discovered that although some elements are present in a single capability, other elements are shared with more than one capability, a phenomenon we named element transversality. The findings allowed us to identify and integrate internal and external elements of capabilities that significantly enhance startups' overall performance. This study proposes a framework that captures the complex overlaps between technological and non-technological capabilities by advancing the theorizing process regarding startup innovation capabilities. The framework also considers that innovation capabilities can boost four types of startup performance: innovation, financial, operational, and market performance, which together form the overall performance. This framework can serve as a driver for resource investment (e.g., capital and time) by startups to build or mature their innovation capabilities and achieve superior performance toward business consolidation.

detail.abstract: The emergence of digital governance has reformed the way governments engage with citizens, providing preeminent opportunities for efficiency, transparency and accountability. Notwithstanding, the implementation of digital governance initiatives also poses significant challenges including concerns over inadequate digital infrastructure, digital illiteracy among citizens and public officials, legal ambiguities, unreliable electricity supply, limited broadband access and cybersecurity concerns. This study navigates the digital frontier of the challenges and prospects of e-governance. A key finding of this study is restricted access to high-speed internet services and unreliable power supply which significantly impede the functionality of e-governance platforms across various government institutions. The work concludes that realising the e-government potential requires addressing infrastructural deficits, expanding digital literacy initiatives, strengthening cybersecurity mechanisms, providing adequate financial funding, establishing robust legal and policy frameworks and fostering a cultural receptive to technological changes.

detail.title: Production Function as a Set of Discrete Options: Neoclassical, Net Zero, and Climate Neutrality
detail.abstract: This study examines the relationship between the neoclassical, net-zero, and climate neutrality perspectives, an area that has received limited attention in formal economic analysis. Adopting the concept of factor substitution, we model the production function as a set of discrete, substitutable options to explore the properties and interactions of these three perspectives. The findings demonstrate that each perspective yields a non-empty subset of solution options. Climate neutrality solutions are situated between neoclassical and net-zero solutions, exhibit discrete convexity, and are influenced by the level of GHG credit costs. Lower GHG credit costs tend to favour neoclassical solutions, while higher costs shift preference toward netzero solutions. This highlights the importance of GHG credit pricing in guiding the transition to a low-emissions economy. Moreover, the framework enables the categorization of new climate mitigation options based on their effects, whether they are irrelevant, complementary, or disruptive. Overall, the proposed model provides an alternative formal approach that enhances the economic analysis of climate change mitigation strategies.

detail.abstract: International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS), which are being adopted as a means of international standardization of accounting, are said to have characteristics that differ from US standards and Japanese standards in terms of their adoption of a principles-based approach. Principle-based accounting is based on the philosophy of aiming for the ideal form of financial reporting without being bound by detailed rules in the relationship between auditors and companies preparing financial reports. However, in the actual application of these principles-that is, when preparing financial statements in accordance with the standards and conducting audits of such statements-auditors or companies must adopt different approaches compared to traditional practices (Nobes, 2005; Benston, Bromwich, and Wagenhofer, 2006a, 2006b, etc.). This paper examines specific accounting events that give rise to judgmental variability in audit judgments, focusing on revenue recognition for software, which requires complex judgments such as estimates, and discusses the relationship between the various types of audit judgment criteria and the actual responses of auditors. We demonstrate, with concrete examples, that regardless of whether the applicable audit standards follow a rule-based or principle-based approach, auditors form a basis for judgment-often referred to as "Auditor GAAP"-to fill gaps in the standards. This role becomes particularly significant when transitioning to a principle-based approach.

detail.abstract: We consider a model of a single defendant and N plaintiffs where the total cost of litigation is fixed on the part of the plaintiffs and shared among the members of a suing coalition. By settling and dropping out of the coalition, a plaintiff therefore creates a negative externality on the other plaintiffs. It was shown in Che and Spier (2008) that failure to internalize this externality can often be exploited by the defendant. However, if plaintiffs make sequential take-it-or-leave-it settlement offers, we can show that they will actually be exploited by one of their fellow plaintiffs rather than by the defendant. When we relax the assumptions, allowing each party to have positive bargaining power, the result lies between the two cases, and the plaintiffs can be exploited jointly by a fellow plaintiff and the defendant.Moreover, if litigation is a public good as is the case in shareholder derivative suits, parties may fail to reach a settlement even having complete information. This may explain why we observe derivative suits in the US but not in Europe.

AI.tldr: 本文研究了原告联盟中单个被告与N个原告的诉讼模型，指出原告退出联盟会对其他原告产生负外部性。研究发现，原告可能被其他原告或被告利用，且公共物品性质的诉讼可能导致和解失败。

title: Attribution of Responsibility in Accounting Firm Service Failures: The Effect of Generative AI Promotion on Client Perceptions
affiliations: East Carolina University - Department of Accounting

detail.title: Attribution of Responsibility in Accounting Firm Service Failures: The Effect of Generative AI Promotion on Client Perceptions

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declares no conflicts of interest related to this research.
declarations.funderStatement: This research did not receive any grant or external funding.

detail.abstract: Accounting firms are investing heavily in generative AI and increasingly promoting these investments as central to their service models. While such messaging signals innovation and efficiency, it may also influence how clients assign blame when service errors occur. Drawing on attribution theory, this study employs a between-subjects experimental design to test whether clients assign responsibility for errors differently based on a firm’s marketing emphasis on generative AI versus traditional services. Participants read a scenario in which a firm-prepared tax return contained errors. In one condition, the accounting firm’s marketing highlighted its use of generative AI tools; in the other, it emphasized a focus on traditional services. The source of the error was left ambiguous. Participants exposed to AI-promoting messaging attributed more blame for the errors to the firm, perceived it as having greater control over error prevention, and judged the errors as more likely to recur. These findings suggest that promoting generative AI in firm marketing may raise client expectations about control and reliability, increasing reputational risk even when the technology’s role in an error is unclear. The study contributes to research on attribution in professional services and highlights a potential tradeoff: firms that emphasize technological sophistication may also be seen as more culpable when things go wrong.

AI.tldr: 研究发现，会计公司在营销中强调生成式AI会增加客户对错误的归责，提升公司声誉风险。

AI.practical_contributions: 提醒会计公司在推广新技术时需权衡技术优势与潜在的声誉风险。

title: Accounting for Spatial Effects and Social Norms in Making Algorithmic Law: Insights from and Applications in Urban Mobility
affiliations: University of Illinois College of Law

detail.title: Accounting for Spatial Effects and Social Norms in Making Algorithmic Law: Insights from and Applications in Urban Mobility

publicationDetails.detailsText: University of Michigan Journal of Law and Mobility (forthcoming)

detail.abstract: This article examines the idea in the law and technology literature that algorithms and big data could be used to make the law dynamic and personalized and shows that algorithmic law, as previously envisioned, would often do more harm than good. Laws made by algorithms can adjust in real-time to changing circumstances and vary for each individual based on personal characteristics. Making the law dynamic can increase its effectiveness. However, the personalization component of previous conceptions of algorithmic law is problematic. Algorithmic law, as conceived by other scholars, is made only using individual characteristics and fails to account for the interactive effects of individual behavior. The roles of spatial effects, social norms, additional law enforcement costs, externalities, and the unpredictability of complex systems where law and behavior have feedback effects are unaccounted for when the lawmaker attempts to make the law to maximize welfare based on only individual characteristics. Welfare maximization based only on individual characteristics does not necessarily result in welfare maximization in the aggregate or even welfare maximization for each individual. Examples from urban mobility illustrate the problems of creating algorithmic law based only on individual characteristics and the necessity of adequately incorporating interactive effects into the process of using algorithms to customize the law for each individual. This article proposes a method for making algorithmic law that assumes that every activity is interactive and adequately accounts for the interactive effects of individual behavior, particularly in terms of spatial effects and social norms. Whereas under previous proposals, lawmakers create the law for each individual separately, lawmakers using this process would make combinations of coordinated laws for all individuals simultaneously, and the coordinated laws would collectively maximize social welfare in each case. The result of applying this process is not making the law more differentiated but maintaining uniformity in the law in many situations.

AI.tldr: 本文探讨了法律与技术文献中关于算法和大数据使法律动态化和个性化的观点，指出传统设想的算法法律可能弊大于利。动态化可提升法律效果，但个性化部分存在问题，因其未考虑个体行为的互动效应。文章提出新方法，将互动效应纳入算法法律制定过程，以最大化社会福利。
AI.research_question: 算法和大数据能否使法律动态化和个性化？传统设想的算法法律是否存在问题？
AI.motivation: 探讨算法法律的实际效果及其潜在问题，提出改进方法以避免传统设想的弊端。
AI.theoretical_framework: 法律动态化与个性化理论、社会福利最大化理论、互动效应理论（空间效应、社会规范等）。
AI.method: 通过分析传统算法法律的缺陷，提出一种新方法，将互动效应纳入法律制定过程。
AI.findings: 传统算法法律因忽视互动效应可能导致社会福利下降；新方法通过协调法律组合，能更有效地最大化社会福利。
AI.theory_contributions: 提出互动效应在算法法律中的重要性，丰富了法律动态化与个性化的理论框架。
AI.practical_contributions: 为政策制定者提供改进算法法律的方法，避免传统设想的弊端，提升法律的实际效果。

title: The Perils of Artificial Intelligence and Underdeveloped Targeting Law
affiliations: University of Minnesota Law School

detail.title: The Perils of Artificial Intelligence and Underdeveloped Targeting Law
detail.abstract: Extant IHL insufficiently defines membership in an organized armed group for targeting purposes.  This deficiency is worrying in its own right but may dramatically undermine IHL's protective purposes as lethal autonomous weapons systems and other targeting systems powered by artificial intelligence are directed toward human targets.  This chapter illustrates IHL's shortcomings in this respect by examining three approaches to assigning OAG membership:  the United States' pre-9/11 "individual belligerency" framework; the United States' post-9/11 conduct-based approach; and the International Committee for the Red Cross' functional test.

AI.tldr: 现有国际人道法（IHL）对组织武装团体成员身份的定义不足，可能削弱其保护目的，尤其是在人工智能驱动的武器系统针对人类目标时。本章通过分析三种成员身份认定方法，揭示了IHL的缺陷。
AI.research_question: 国际人道法如何定义组织武装团体的成员身份，以适用于目标识别？
AI.motivation: 现有IHL对成员身份定义不足，可能因人工智能武器的使用而削弱其保护作用，亟需探讨。
AI.theoretical_framework: 国际人道法（IHL）、组织武装团体成员身份理论。
AI.method: 分析三种成员身份认定方法：美国9/11前的“个体交战”框架、9/11后的行为导向方法、国际红十字会的功能测试。
AI.findings: 现有IHL在成员身份定义上存在缺陷，可能导致保护目的被削弱。

title: Dha-Fl: Dynamic Hierarchical Attention Aggregation Framework for Heterogeneous Edge Federated Learning
affiliations: Guangzhou College of Commerce and Guangzhou College of Commerce

detail.title: Dha-Fl: Dynamic Hierarchical Attention Aggregation Framework for Heterogeneous Edge Federated Learning
detail.abstract: The challenges of low convergence efficiency and increased communication overhead due to device heterogeneity pose significant obstacles to the implementation of federated learning in industrial contexts. This paper introduces a dynamic hierarchical attention aggregation framework that optimizes device resources adaptively through an entropy-temperature co-evolution mechanism. First, we develop a quantitative metric system to assess device heterogeneity, resulting in a comprehensive scoring model that considers computational power, communication quality, and data distribution bias. Next, we create a temperature-driven dynamic hierarchical approach that classifies devices into fast and slow tiers based on their entropy values, allowing for differentiated weight aggregation via an attention mechanism. We also propose an entropy-triggered resource scheduling method to dynamically reduce communication traffic and utilize lightweight models. Experimental results show that this framework significantly improves convergence speed and lowers system overhead while preserving model accuracy. It demonstrates strong resilience in highly heterogeneous environments and non-IID data, offering an effective federated learning solution for resource-limited situations, such as industrial IoT.

AI.tldr: 本文提出了一种动态分层注意力聚合框架，通过熵-温度协同进化机制优化设备资源，显著提升了联邦学习在异构设备环境中的收敛效率和通信效率。

title: A Model of Tokenized Marketplaces
affiliations: University of Florida - Information Systems and Operations Management and Purdue University - Department of Consumer Sciences and Retailing

detail.title: A Model of Tokenized Marketplaces
detail.abstract: We develop an analytical model that demonstrates the economic value of utility tokens as a means to reduce reliance on intermediaries by showing how marketplace tokenization enhances market efficiency (i.e., total profitability) and improves consumer welfare. Specifically, we propose a token-based framework for digital marketplaces and show that tokenization functions as an incentive mechanism that alleviates underproduction by producers without compromising their payoffs, thereby mitigating the price inflation often associated with conventional intermediaries. Furthermore, tokenization incentivizes platforms to profitably transition away from commission-based revenue models. This shift is enabled through decentralized control: the platform is responsible for ICO issuance as compensation for relinquishing its conventional intermediary role; transaction validation is carried out by independent contributors; and tips to these contributors are set by producers. Our findings remain robust across settings with multiple producers, whether their product demands are independent, complementary, or substitutable, and consistently show that our proposed decentralized control mechanism leads to higher output.

AI.tldr: 本文通过分析模型展示了实用代币的经济价值，证明其能减少对中介的依赖，提升市场效率和消费者福利。代币化作为激励机制，缓解生产者的低产问题，同时避免价格通胀，并促使平台从佣金模式转向去中心化控制。

title: Financial Results of Foreign Businesses in Russia in 2024
affiliations: Kyiv School of Economics, Kyiv School of Economics and Kyiv School of Economics

detail.title: Financial Results of Foreign Businesses in Russia in 2024

keywords: share of foreign companies in Russia

detail.abstract:
1. Foreign companies are gradually closing their financial reporting. As of June 2025, only 70% of all legal entities owned by foreign owners have submitted financial statements for the previous year. Reporting is primarily withheld by the largest companies. Among the 100 largest foreign players in 2021, 86 reported for 2023, while only 43 did so for 2024. Smaller companies continue to submit data relatively steadily. This may indicate coordination of reporting with the Kremlin. Therefore, for the largest companies, to make year-to-year comparisons partially relevant, we are forced to extrapolate data from previous years in the absence of current data.
2. The revenue of companies owned by foreigners before the full-scale invasion of Ukraine amounted to USD 201 billion in 2024. This is nearly the same as in 2023 (USD 198 billion) and significantly less than in 2021, when revenue was USD 320 billion. It can be concluded that the exit of foreign companies from the Russian market has halted, reaching a "plateau" in this process.
3. The main part of this revenue is generated by companies classified by the KSE Institute as “stay” status — these account for 68% of the total, or USD 136 billion. The remainder belongs to companies still in the process of exiting or those that have already transferred ownership (usually to local owners). There are more than 400 such companies, accounting for a quarter of the revenue (USD 50 billion) in 2024.
4. Owners from Kremlin-friendly countries, such as China or Turkey, are playing an increasingly active role. In 2021, “unfriendly” countries (a term used by the Kremlin referring to countries that did not condemn or directly supported Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, continue active trade or cooperation with Russia despite sanctions, and block or soften international initiatives against Russia) accounted for 95% of the revenue of foreign businesses in Russia. By 2024, this figure decreased to 82%. The main beneficiary is China, whose share grew from 2.7% to 14%. This also slows the process of further exits. Notably, the share of companies from the United States in total revenue has remained almost unchanged at around 19%, similar to the pre-invasion level of 20%.
5. A separate issue concerns the performance results of companies that have already left the Russian market and, in most cases, have transferred ownership to local managers. Their share accounted for 25% of the total revenue of USD 201 billion in 2024. Most of these ownership changes occurred in 2022 and 2023. For example, if the share of sold companies in total revenue was 34% in the pre-war year, it decreased to 25% by 2024. This indicates that new local managers have not been able to restore pre-sale performance levels, raising questions about their ability to keep the business afloat.
6. Net profit/loss in 2024 amounted to USD 19.5 billion — a record for the last three years (it was USD 1 billion less in 2021). Taxes paid have hardly changed compared to the pre-war year (USD 5.6 billion). These figures may indicate that foreign companies, especially those from Kremlin-friendly countries such as China and Turkey, continue to operate in a less competitive environment with higher business margins, even amid declining overall turnover.
7. Paid corporate income taxes have slightly decreased (to USD 6 billion), but the total tax burden — including excise taxes and others — is difficult to assess, not least due to the opacity of financial reporting and completely closed information on certain types of taxes. In a typical company with average profitability (margin of 10–20%), the tax burden from total revenue is around 10–15%. Previously, we estimated the total taxes paid by foreign companies to be between USD 20–30 billion.

title: Home Bias and Flight-to-Safety in the Crypto Economy: Evidence from Korea's 2021 Regulatory Reform
affiliations: College of Business, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology (KAIST), Case Western Reserve University, Hong Kong University of Science & Technology (HKUST) - Department of Information & Systems Management, Seoul National University and College of Business, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology (KAIST)

detail.title: Home Bias and Flight-to-Safety in the Crypto Economy: Evidence from Korea's 2021 Regulatory Reform
detail.abstract: Although cryptocurrency markets are increasingly subject to regulation worldwide, little is known about how retail investors respond to such regulatory changes. We address this question by exploiting South Korea's 2021 Know Your Customer (KYC) reform as a natural experiment to examine how crosscountry regulatory differences shape cryptocurrency flows. Our analysis reveals a "crypto home bias with flight-to-safety," whereby retail investors respond to regulatory tightening by reallocating assets toward large, compliant domestic exchanges rather than engaging in cross-border regulatory arbitrage. This flight-to-safety behavior is particularly pronounced among smaller investors, whose share of total deposits flowing into South Korea's largest exchanges increased significantly following the regulatory shift. We further find that reserves at noncompliant exchanges declined sharply-by 61.7% relative to compliant domestic counterparts-indicating heightened investor sensitivity to platform risk. These results suggest that retail investors prioritize domestic regulatory compliance and platform safety, highlighting how local regulatory shocks in supranational cryptocurrency markets can trigger flight-to-safety dynamics driven by investor risk aversion and home bias.

AI.tldr: 本文通过韩国2021年的KYC改革作为自然实验，研究了零售投资者对加密货币监管变化的反应，发现投资者倾向于将资产重新配置到合规的国内大型交易所，而非跨境套利，表现出明显的“安全偏好”和“本土偏好”。
AI.research_question: 零售投资者如何应对加密货币市场的监管变化？
AI.motivation: 全球加密货币市场监管日益加强，但零售投资者对监管变化的反应尚不明确。
AI.theoretical_framework: 行为金融学中的“安全偏好”和“本土偏好”理论。
AI.method: 利用韩国2021年KYC改革作为自然实验，分析跨市场监管差异对加密货币流动的影响。
AI.findings: 投资者在监管收紧时将资产转移到合规的国内大型交易所，小型投资者尤为明显；不合规交易所的储备金下降了61.7%。
AI.theory_contributions: 揭示了零售投资者在监管变化下的行为模式，验证了“安全偏好”和“本土偏好”理论在加密货币市场的适用性。
AI.practical_contributions: 为监管机构提供了关于零售投资者行为的实证依据，强调了合规和平台安全的重要性。

title: Feature Enrichment Imitative Reinforcement Learning for High-Frequency Trading
affiliations: Jiangsu University, Jiangsu University of Science and Technology, Jiangsu University and Department of Computer Science, School of Engineering & Computer Science, Baylor University

detail.title: Feature Enrichment Imitative Reinforcement Learning for High-Frequency Trading
detail.abstract: High-frequency trading (HFT) requires rapid, adaptive decision-making in volatile markets, yet balancing exploration (discovering new profitable strategies) and exploitation (capitalizing on known opportunities) remains challenging. We introduce a novel tIRDPG-LID, a twin-imitation recurrent deterministic policy gradient model that learns from imperfect demonstrations, to address partial observability and overestimation bias in feature-scarce HFT scenarios. Our approach enriches the feature space via feature interpolation to mitigate the scarcity typical in HFT, then uses a trajectory discrimination mechanism and dynamic weighting to integrate and filter imperfect demonstration data. The trajectory discrimination mechanism compares each demonstration's performance to the agent's current returns and only emphasizes those expert actions that yield a positive advantage. Simultaneously, twin critics with delayed actor updates stabilize training under high volatility, reducing estimation errors and excessive risk. We provide a rigorous theoretical framework based on data entropy, showing how enriched features improve agent performance under partially observable conditions. Empirical evaluations on large-scale CSI 300 (IF) and CSI 500 (IC) futures confirm that tIRDPG-LID statistically significantly outperforms standard baselines by consistently delivering higher returns and improved risk adjusted metrics. Beyond HFT, the ability of the method to fuse imperfect demonstrations, mitigate overestimation bias, and adapt in real time suggests a wider applicability in other domains where data are scarce or partially observed. By uniting twin critics, imitation learning, and feature-space enrichment under a formal theoretical lens, tIRDPG-LID not only provides a novel solution for Fintech practice, but also extends deep reinforcement learning techniques more generally.

AI.tldr: 本文提出了一种名为tIRDPG-LID的新型模型，用于解决高频交易中探索与利用的平衡问题，通过特征插值和轨迹判别机制提升性能，并在理论和实证上验证了其优越性。
AI.research_question: 如何在高频交易中平衡探索与利用，同时解决部分可观测性和高估偏差问题？
AI.motivation: 高频交易中特征稀缺和部分可观测性导致决策困难，现有方法难以平衡探索与利用。
AI.theoretical_framework: 基于数据熵的理论框架，说明特征插值如何提升部分可观测条件下的性能。
AI.method: 提出tIRDPG-LID模型，结合特征插值、轨迹判别机制和双评论家延迟更新，以整合和筛选不完美的示范数据。
AI.findings: 在CSI 300和CSI 500期货数据上的实证表明，tIRDPG-LID显著优于基线模型，提供更高收益和更好的风险调整指标。
AI.theory_contributions: 扩展了深度强化学习技术，提出了一种融合不完美示范和减轻高估偏差的新方法。
AI.practical_contributions: 为高频交易提供了一种实用解决方案，并展示了在其他数据稀缺或部分可观测领域的潜在应用。

title: Red, Blue & Purple Data Breach Laws: What they Reveal
affiliations: Winthrop University, Kelley School of Business, Winthrop University, Winthrop University and Winthrop University

detail.title: Red, Blue & Purple Data Breach Laws: What they Reveal
detail.abstract: The increase in data breaches is a serious threat to the protection of consumer information. Timely notification of the consumers' vulnerability after a breach is essential. Currently, in the U.S., no federal data breach notification law exists. Given the advancements of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and its potential for a greater and more critical role in our daily lives, the lack of federal breach legislation is of even greater concern. The issue for operating American businesses is that currently each state has their own law. Given the Internet of Things, and the fact that businesses have customers located in different states, without a federal law, businesses need to figure out each states' law and comply with each. Additionally, the multiple state laws with their varying requirements makes it burdensome for companies to comply. Addressing these concerns, this article reviews the U.S. data breach notification laws at the state level to inform the drafting of a much-needed federal law. We analyze the content of the laws considering when they were enacted, the definition of personal information, the notification deadline, and the regulatory strictness which we define as the combination of biometrics, restricted reporting deadlines, and health/medical information. We hypothesized that: (1) the contents of the laws have changed from their original content, (2) there is a relationship between the contents of the law and when the original law was passed, and (3) one political party would dominate when the original law was passed. We found our first hypothesis to be true that the laws have changed content from their original passage. Approximately 70% of the state laws have been amended. Our research also supports our second hypothesis that.

AI.findings: 70%的州法律内容已修改，法律内容与通过时间相关。
AI.theory_contributions: 揭示了法律演变的动态特征及其与政治背景的关系。

title: Disaggregating Digital Rights: The Civil Rights-Civil Liberties Disconnect by
affiliations: Georgetown University Law Center

detail.title: Disaggregating Digital Rights: The Civil Rights-Civil Liberties Disconnect by
detail.abstract:
Civil rights and civil liberties have long existed in tension within U.S. communication and information law and policy—a tension rooted in the very architecture of communication technologies. Broadcast media, being scarce and resource-intensive, invited regulation to ensure it was available for equitable use. In contrast, the early Internet’s abundance and openness gave rise to a civil libertarian ethos focused on individual freedom and minimal state involvement.

This Article traces how public interest communication and information policy advocacy has shifted between these paradigms across three eras. First, a civil rights­–oriented media justice movement flourished from the 1950s to the 1990s. Second, communication-information policy advocacy took a civil libertarian turn during the rise of the Internet from the 1990s to 2013. Third, from 2013 to the present day, an American racial justice reckoning, coupled with a growing reckoning with how data-driven technologies can reinforce inequality, has driven efforts to reconcile the civil rights–civil liberties disconnect.

Viewed through this lens, the civil rights–civil liberties disconnect emerges as a key factor in the success or failure of public interest advocacy campaigns. When organizations bridge the divide, their coalitions grow and campaigns are politically stronger. When they don’t, they risk fractured alliances, weakened framing, and policy proposals that fall short. This article argues that public interest organizations must confront and actively engage this tension. A deliberate realignment that embraces both liberty and equity is essential to meeting the substantial challenges of the current moment.

AI.tldr: 本文探讨了美国通信与信息法律政策中公民权利与公民自由之间的长期紧张关系，分析了这种紧张关系如何在不同时代影响公共利益倡导运动。
AI.research_question: 美国通信与信息法律政策中公民权利与公民自由的紧张关系如何影响公共利益倡导运动的成功或失败？
AI.motivation: 研究动机源于公民权利与公民自由在通信技术架构中的固有矛盾，以及这种矛盾在不同历史时期对政策倡导的影响。
AI.theoretical_framework: 基于通信技术的稀缺性与开放性理论，以及公民权利与公民自由的范式对比。
AI.method: 通过历史分析，将政策倡导分为三个时代：1950-1990年代的媒体正义运动、1990-2013年的互联网自由转向，以及2013年至今的种族正义与数据技术不平等问题。
AI.findings: 研究发现，公民权利与公民自由的脱节是公共利益倡导运动成败的关键因素。成功案例往往能弥合两者分歧，而失败案例则因未能解决这一矛盾而削弱了联盟和政策提案。
AI.theory_contributions: 理论贡献在于揭示了公民权利与公民自由在通信政策中的动态关系，并提出了弥合两者分歧的必要性。
AI.practical_contributions: 实践贡献在于为公共利益组织提供了策略建议，强调必须主动应对公民权利与公民自由的矛盾，以实现更有效的政策倡导。

title: Reactions to Algorithmic Pricing: a Field Experiment
affiliations: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University

detail.title: Reactions to Algorithmic Pricing: a Field Experiment
detail.abstract: This paper examines the influence of algorithmic dynamic pricing on a storage rental company, considering the shift from human judgment to algorithm-driven decisions. The focus is on "algorithmic pricing," which adjusts prices using advanced analytics. The study explores the impact of this approach on customer interest, purchase behavior, and spending, while also considering sellers' perspectives and the role of algorithms in human-machine collaboration. Through a field experiment with a storage rental company, the research demonstrates that algorithmic pricing increases customer purchase likelihood and interest, leading to higher contract prices. Additionally, sellers' behavior changes post-disclosure, with reduced customer discounts and enhanced trust in algorithms. This study contributes by showcasing algorithmic pricing's effectiveness in boosting spending while maintaining lead generation, and by uncovering how trust in algorithms affects seller behavior, offering insights for optimizing pricing strategies and improving employee-algorithm collaboration.

AI.tldr: 本文研究了算法动态定价对仓储租赁公司的影响，发现其能提高客户购买可能性和兴趣，同时改变卖家行为，增强对算法的信任。
